document.title: South Carolina Academic Standards and Performance Indicators for Science

3E2F62E6625C45A1912A2093F3C524E2.description: Conduct structured investigations to answer questions about which materials have the properties that are best suited to solve a problem or need.

2B121317B12F40E1ABB89CFA04C54416.description: Develop and use models to describe and compare the properties of different materials (including wood, plastic, metal, cloth, and paper) and classify materials by their observable properties, by their uses, and by whether they are natural or human-made.

0CA6631083EE45EF90D574D4402D6383.description: Analyze and interpret data to compare the qualitative properties of objects (such as size, shape, color, texture, weight, flexibility, attraction to magnets, or ability to sink or float) and classify objects based on similar properties.

B2C5511999344C4AA514469598121091.description: Objects can be described and classified by their observable properties, by their uses, and by whether they occur naturally or are manufactured (human-made). Different properties of objects are suited for different purposes.

9D218266139D48A6AD2E65992F80166B.description: The student will demonstrate an understanding of the observable properties of matter.

268D30E577D349DE8C1F82B24E4513DC.description: Physical Science: Exploring Properties of Objects and Materials

3BAC430B2AF8442A921067D4EE125874.description: Define problems caused by the effects of weather on human activities and design solutions or devices to solve the problem.

6FDD192991154BCBA758E838B68F28B5.description: Obtain and communicate information to support claims about how changes in seasons affect plants and animals.

2755C64F30914FCBA0CAA8B73166BA06.description: Develop and use models to predict seasonal weather patterns and changes.

50162E34BFD54CF4B8AECF46B2FA6CAD.description: Analyze and interpret local weather condition data (including precipitation, wind, temperature, and cloud cover) to describe weather patterns that occur from day to day, using simple graphs and pictorial weather symbols.

2829B0BDC7CD4CA986BA96FFE6803423.description: Weather is a combination of sunlight, wind, snow or rain, and temperature in a particular region at a particular time. Scientists measure weather conditions to describe and record the weather and to notice patterns over time. Plants and animals (including humans) respond to different weather conditions in different ways.

57AE5C00223B41EBA7018A92457ABCA5.description: The student will demonstrate an understanding of daily and seasonal weather patterns.

B8325D9A99A74BEF8A3160507ED68FB7.description: Obtain and communicate information about the needs of organisms to explain why they live in particular areas.

E509632197BD4201AAC492D4063B628B.description: Construct explanations from observations of what animals need to survive and grow (including air, water, nutrients, and shelter).

4CAE89A6B4DB4E0D9193DE7C8AFB23B5.description: Analyze and interpret data to describe how humans use their senses to learn about the world around them.

D4B0741248C345F4911E36A90B109C06.description: Develop and use models to exemplify how animals use their body parts to (1) obtain food and other resources, (2) protect themselves, and (3) move from place to place.

040A67708FEC4F49A2D52E136130692E.description: Conduct structured investigations to determine what plants need to live and grow (including water and light).

496D5C6550D140008C6ACE351A9E4A55.description: Obtain information to answer questions about different organisms found in the environment (such as plants, animals, or fungi).

15E6D1D55C51471D9DB5307179C08C41.description: The environment consists of many types of organisms including plants, animals, and fungi. Organisms depend on the land, water, and air to live and grow. Plants need water and light to make their own food. Fungi and animals cannot make their own food and get energy from other sources. Animals (including humans) use different body parts to obtain food and other resources needed to grow and survive. Organisms live in areas where their needs for air, water, nutrients, and shelter are met.

37AB18BD03B943DBAAEDA6193CA83950.description: The student will demonstrate an understanding of organisms found in the environment and how these organisms depend on the environment to meet those needs.

982BD96DF3244E1A9A93674F4786DD82.description: Life Science: Exploring Organisms and the Environment

BACC04A0C25F407DAF2FF2CD3474CD14.description: Construct devices or design solutions to solve specific problems or needs: (1) ask questions to identify problems or needs, (2) ask questions about the criteria and constraints of the devices or solutions, (3) generate and communicate ideas for possible devices or solutions, (4) build and test devices or solutions, (5) determine if the devices or solutions solved the problem, and (6) communicate the results.

359CE844E9A540948012313849C53390.description: Technology is any modification to the natural world created to fulfill the wants and needs of humans. The engineering design process involves a series of iterative steps used to solve a problem and often leads to the development of a new or improved technology.

AF0338326AB04DD9AF47F5F1C00CE090.description: Obtain and evaluate informational texts, observations, data collected, or discussions to (1) generate and answer questions about the natural world, (2) understand phenomena, (3) develop models, or (4) support explanations. Communicate observations and explanations using oral and written language.

684D6EA962C84E72B7F751332D5615ED.description: Construct scientific arguments to support explanations using evidence from observations or data collected.

9265BABD649D4B86835E3A6D7C14FA69.description: Construct explanations of phenomena using (1) student-generated observations and measurements, (2) results of investigations, or (3) data communicated in graphs, tables, or diagrams.

E380B08E948941D8907A6B54FAE5C36E.description: Use mathematical thinking to (1) recognize and express quantitative observations, (2) collect and analyze data, or (3) understand patterns and relationships.

BE8532F5EB1C45EA8CAF6F7718B18338.description: Analyze and interpret data from observations, measurements, or investigations to understand patterns and meanings.

A2B42CD25EEE4AE7A598DDE1FC52EB4C.description: With teacher guidance, conduct structured investigations to answer scientific questions, test predictions and develop explanations: (1) predict possible outcomes, (2) identify materials and follow procedures, (3) use appropriate tools or instruments to make qualitative observations and take nonstandard measurements, and (4) record and represent data in an appropriate form. Use appropriate safety procedures.

E966934F6B8A4845A1F1BEA6100E7C77.description: Develop and use models to (1) understand or represent phenomena, processes, and relationships, (2) test devices or solutions, or (3) communicate ideas to others.

C30F618825B241F1AABDE5EDBB793117.description: Ask and answer questions about the natural world using explorations, observations, or structured investigations.

392BC6A7834D40B5B2694EF12D77636B.description: The practices of science and engineering support the development of science concepts, develop the habits of mind that are necessary for scientific thinking, and allow students to engage in science in ways that are similar to those used by scientists and engineers.

B753D2926FFF4900B5928B8F5E7924DC.description: The student will use the science and engineering practices, including the processes and skills of scientific inquiry, to develop understandings of science content.
